chatgpt_double_star.new_statement: A consensus reform should keep elections run by the states but make the presidential outcome reflect voters more consistently, so neither a handful of battlegrounds nor any single region dominates. The most workable path is to phase out winner-take-all by adopting proportional elector allocation with nationwide baseline rules for ballot access, paper-backed audits, and automatic recount triggers, while requiring electors to follow certified results. If a broad agreement later forms to move fully to a national popular vote, it should be implemented through an orderly amendment or compact with clear procedures for close margins and uniform vote-counting standards.

chatgpt_double_star_rankings.new_statement: Reform should preserve state-run election administration while making presidential outcomes track the national popular will more reliably, so results don’t hinge on winner-take-all math in a few battleground counties. A practical middle path is to end winner-take-all by allocating electors proportionally (or, as an incremental bridge, through the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact), and to require electors to follow certified results. Any model should be paired with clear, uniform national baselines for ballot access, paper-backed post-election audits, and automatic recount triggers so outcomes are verifiable and broadly trusted.

chatgpt_double_star_personas.new_statement: Reform should make presidential outcomes reflect the voters more consistently while keeping elections state-run, secure, and easy to verify, so people in both “safe” and “swing” states feel their vote counts. A practical middle path is to end winner-take-all by moving to proportional allocation of electors (or adopting the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact once it reaches a clear threshold), while binding electors to certified results. Any change should come with simple nationwide baseline rules for ballot access, paper-backed audits, and automatic recount triggers in close races, and states could adopt ranked-choice voting if they want to ensure majority support and reduce spoiler fears.
